comments.body: sure
Maybe default data to `const CupertinoThemeData()` and (unrelated) don't require child to be non null?
Let's keep CupertinoTheme and MaterialTheme the same for now. There's no reason to add a CupertinoTheme without a theme for now. The CupertinoApp adds one with a const CupertinoThemeData already.
It looks like it's only the textTheme that can be partially specified. Might be best to just explain how its null properties are defaulted.
Actually I meant this constructor's parameters can be partially specified. Rather than each one of the parameters can be specified in part.
It would be more conventional to use @required named parameters here.
This is mainly to avoid verbosity for a protected constructor
need a blank line here
I'm just grouping the private fields with the getters
I think what you mean is that, by default, the MaterialTheme creates a CupertinoTheme with the same brightness value.

Some subtle nuances here but it does not. CupertinoThemes under MaterialThemes are specific overrides. If you took that CupertinoThemeData and put it under a different MaterialTheme, it would use that new MaterialTheme's brightness. It wouldn't work if that CupertinoThemeData was constructed with the first material theme's brightness.

OK, so it's:

By default, the MaterialTheme creates a CupertinoTheme that inherits the MaterialTheme's [ThemeData.brightness].
I will not belabor this trivial point any further but: "derived from" sounds more complicated than simple copying.  In this case "will be derived from" could just be "the same as".
Ya same as below. It doesn't copy it. The actual value at that node is null. It defers the value to the ancestor material theme.
do we actually need this? we only need it in ThemeData because the default constructor does all kinds of magic.

I just needed 2 different constructors for optional arguments and required arguments. But you point below about the raw constructor and method overlap is a good point. I'll rename this (since it's `@protected` and less important).
this explanation really doesn't help anyone who doesn't understand the subtleties of the class hierarchy here.
added more text
it's very confusing that CupertinoThemeData.raw() doesn't return the same thing as CupertinoThemeData().raw()
Changed the non-constructor method to noDefault() instead since it's more explicit
